title: A Novel Approach and Practical Algorithms for Ontology Integration

author: Giorgos Stoilos, Computing Laboratory, Oxford University

segmentation: This is joint work with David Guetta, Jetta Hendershot Masoni and Mohammed GoDaddy.
All of us are knowledge engineers in Babylon Health and today I'm going to present you our approach of how we are building the medical knowledge base in Babylon.
So.
A few words about Babylon.
First, Babylon offers digital health care services.
At the moment we are mostly operating in the UK and mainly in London and also in Rhonda, but we're expanding globally.
So recently we had the some deals with health care providers to go into the Canada market as well as in took ten countries in Asia.

And the two main services that domain products of Babylon offers is a video consultation where you can talk to ATP via your mobile phone, your smartphone and the second part is symptom checking chat bot where you can go in, put your symptoms and you're going to be guided through task oriented dialogue system in.
At the end proposed the system can propose your potential.
Taking of yourselves symptoms and then maybe offer you to talk to at GP and arrange an appointment.
So these two main products are backed up by AI based technologies and services.
We're doing a NLP and text processing.
We also have machine learning team and we of course have our probabilistic symptom taking edging, which is it's currently being built by by epidemiologists, doctors and machine learning scientists.
And at the core of all these services we are building the medical knowledge base that we want all services to use.
In order to communicate with each other so the medical knowledge base does offer the common vocabulary so every service can go and pick.
I arise from our knowledge base, but on.
Apart from that, we also wanted to offer more more advanced reasoning services in order for all the services to communicate with each other.
So there is some story behind how we reached the point now.
So at the beginning we tried to use some kind of linked data approach in order to build our knowledge base.
There are plenty of biomedical datasets out there.
Is there is the bio two RDF?
Umm lesson bioportal efforts.
It is very easy to build this approach.
You can just take RDF data from export that RDF data from these data sources and put them together.

Is easy to implement, but comes with some problems and some of these problems are that the sources in this cloud are not very well interconnected.
There is duplication.
There is ambiguity.
UM LS, for example, contains for the different high rise for malaria.
And so all these were creating some kind of issues.
It wasn't easy for us to build services on top of.
On top of this cloud.
So the new approach with the work today is about.
Is that then we?
We thought about why, why to put all these sources together, not just focusing to two sources, or that I'm trying to align them together by computing set of mappings and then integrate them.
This will of course create a medical knowledge base that has a higher degree of integration, because we're going to be able to identify the common areas for malaria.
Integrate the information from the two different sources.

We can monitor how our knowledge base is grown because it grows one source at the time, and we're not exporting all this huge amount of information that existing buyers who are there for you, molesting, putting them, putting it to their to leave.
But of course there are still many challenges and the main challenges that all this data sources, they have taxonomies that may come into disagreement and in conflict.

So for example, in FMA, FMA, ontology, you have an action that says that proteins are anatomical structures, whereas in Sonoma you have an action that is saying that proteins are substances, and this to come into conflict.
Conflicts can cause inconsistencies in equal shares.

So for example, if Snowman is telling us that substance substance is a disjoint class with anatomical structures and you try to integrate into snowmen, VFM, a year he you're going to end up with an unsatisfiable concepts.

But even even if the ontology doesn't contain such a strong statements about disjointness of axioms bringing together here his may create confusion or service and unpredictability, because at some point while our services are operating, you know some things about about the entity entities in their knowledge base.
So for example, you may know that this X11 entities substance, and then after you align and integrate a new data source in your system.
Maybe this annotation service now is telling you that this entity is a substance as it was before, but it's now for some reason became a body part as well.

And there are test regression tests behind all our services in Babylon and this can create confusion to doctors or or other users of the knowledge base, but also cause of failure for tests that other systems other services are using.
But there is a notion there is a notion in the literature that can help us solve this problem, and the notion is that conservativity.
So what is the cost of activity?
Conservative alignment is a set of mappings between two ontologies that do not alter the structure of an ontology.
So if you have two ontologies, your first computer set of alignment between them, and then you discover that this set of alignment is is causing some.
Conflicts and violations between the errors of the ontologies.
Then you want to compute the subset of this set of mappings in order to repair these violations.

There have been many assistance proposed in the past and implemented and techniques, but the main way that system so far have been repairing this taxonomical violations is by removing mappings from the set of alignments that they have computed.
And dropping mappings from the alignment.
Unfortunately it does.

On the one hand, it does repair the violations between the two ontologies, but unfortunately introduces new another problem because by dropping mappings, basically you're somehow cancelling what you initially wanted to do with, which was to compute alignment between the ontologies.
So first you compute them and then you start to remove them.
So you somehow cancelling this.

And by canceling this and not mapping to entities and integrate them, you end up again with the same problem that we had when we first started with the link data approach which is having different classes in your knowledge base that speak about the same entity.
So you had malaria in one ontology, malaria in the other ontology, you align them and then for some reason you drop the mapping.
So again you end up with two classes that have overlapping labels and this again introduces ambiguity it.
It creates a knowledge base which is very large in size.

I don't code malaria and another service.

Violations and don't draw mappings, so our idea is the following.
So we said why?
Why don't we consider one of the two ontologies as.
Our main conceptualization?
Is the conceptualization over with our services are currently, let's say, operate.
It's a data source that we trust.
And why don't we use the new ontologies that we want to bring in as like a secondary sources that we can use in order to enrich our current version of and of the knowledge base?

And by doing this we thought OK, then we can maybe repair these violations not by dropping Bob mappings, but by dropping actions from the ontology that we're trying to use in order to enrich our data source.

So they create a violation in the previous light I was showing how the current systems fix this violation by dropping the mappings and introducing two concepts.

Venue ontology that you, the new data sources that you want to import.
You can either delete this subclass of axiom or delete this subclass of action.
So either way, either way can repair your violation and you end up with these two integrated sources.
You have no duplication of labels as you had before, and you have a high degree of integration.

Unfortunately, by dropping mappings from the imported ontology doesn't necessarily repair all the violations that you have in your in your current knowledge base, and this is the case with mappings of higher multiplicity.
So their mapping algorithm may have computed two mappings and.
These mappings may tell you that you need basically to merge two concepts in your initial knowledge base, and this creates a violation because you didn't have before that C is equivalent to be, but.
The mappings now implying to you that these two concepts are the same.
So you have a violation that is not really coming by the axioms that you want to import from the ontology, but it's coming from this higher multiplicity mappings.
So in this case, the only way that you can repair these these violations is by dropping one of the two mappings.
You cannot do anything else.

So this slide summarizes our approach and the idea of fixing fixing into some giving higher priority into some conceptualization of an ontology of our current knowledge base, and then changing the set of mappings only when it is absolutely necessary.
As so do you in the previous slide in mappings of higher multiplicity and fixing all the other violations by trying to drop mappings from the imported.
From the imported ontology.
We have tried to formalize our framework.
We have the definition of a safe extension which basically tries to capture the notion that I was describing before.

So instead of just instead of saying that we want to compute a subset of the mappings that the mapping algorithm computed, you can now compute definition allows you to also compute a subset of the ontology that you want to import.

And we have shown that the algorithm that we implement it computes a safe extension if the last part where you decide which set of actions to drop from the from the ontology that you're importing is implemented using the old plans algorithm, which has been described in the literature.
Fortunately, the old plans algorithm does not scale in practice because it is exponential, but in order to overcome this issue, have implemented an approximate.
Technique to decide which actions to drop from the imported ontology and this approximate algorithms is based in somehow in pattern based identification of the violations which has been.
It is quite closer to work that was published in 2009.
We have implemented our approach into quite modular pipeline we can use.
Any existing matching algorithm internally, but at the current moment our pipeline mostly we are using a custom in-house implementation of a simple exact label matter.
It is simple, but it has very high precision, which is something that is very important in our reduced case because we don't want to say that two medical entities are the same and these are not.
And cost quite good.
Fair enough recall.
Actually I would say it has almost similar recall to existing state of the art matching systems for the medical for the medical domain.

So in the evaluation, we wanted to compare our approach on fixing this conservativity violations against other systems in the literature that also tried to fix violations in the imported ontologies and they based their matching approach into onto this conservativity violation.

We did two experiments.
One was starting with Nomad.
We wanted to match Nomad against NCI.
And then against FMA and import NSI and FMA and then measure the violations.
So there are three key things to note.
First of all, our approach scaled quite well.
Neither log mark nor AML could scale on the full size of snowmen and NCI, and therefore in order to try and get some idea and results about how well they fix their violations.
We fragmented, we try to fragment the ontologies using some kind of modularization techniques and apply these systems on its module.

But still after we managed to do that as you can see, our approach was the only one that was able to repair all the violations in in the ontologies, whereas in both log map and AML you could still identify number quite a large number of violations on the imported on our knowledge base as an important new data source.
We also try to measure ambiguity, which is something that it is.
It is a very important metric in our case because we don't want labels to appear in multiple classes in the ontology.
As you can see in our approach.
Our approach created knowledge base with the smallest ambiguity in both log map and AML case.
We had many more classes with duplicate labels.
And.

Finally, after finishing our experiment and taking about conservativity capability, so far approach versus others we wanted, we started using the pipeline in order to build to actually build the knowledge base in Babylon.
We started from Snow Med because we felt that it is a high quality data source and then we add it iteratively, NCI CSV and FMA.
These are some numbers.

About the size of our knowledge base when we submitted the paper, but since then we have continued extending the knowledge base and now we have integrated many more sources like a snowman, UK and drug extensions, ICD 9 and ICD 10, and we have a knowledge base that we have reached the current poet knowledge base that contains 1 million classes, 12 million subclass of actions and 3 million properties.
